content: The "Federal Executive Accountability Act of 2017" is also known as the Office of Inspector General in the Executive Office of the President. The "Federal Executive Accountability Act of 2017" amends the Inspector General Act of 1978 to include the President in the appointment of the Inspector General for the Executive Office of the President. The President must appoint an individual within 120 days of the Act's enactment. The Inspector General Act of 1978 is amended to include special provisions for the Executive Office of the President. The Inspector General Act of 1978 is amended to include special provisions for the Executive Office of the President, specifically in Section 8N. The Inspector General Act of 1978 is amended to include special provisions for the Executive Office of the President, specifically in Section 8N. The President has authority, direction, and control over audits, investigations, and issuance of subpoenas by the Inspector General of the Executive Office of the President in certain situations involving confidential sources, intelligence matters, or undercover operations. The President can prohibit the Inspector General of the Executive Office of the President from conducting audits, investigations, or issuing subpoenas to prevent the disclosure of certain information. If the President exercises this power, they must notify the Inspector General in writing within 30 days, explaining the reasons for the prohibition. The President can prohibit the Inspector General from conducting audits, investigations, or issuing subpoenas to prevent disclosure of information. The Inspector General must notify specific congressional committees within 30 days of receiving the notice. The Inspector General's semiannual reports to Congress must include descriptions of completed corrective actions, certification of access to relevant information, and details of any audits or inspections conducted. The Inspector General's semiannual reports to Congress must include descriptions of audits, inspections, and evaluations where relevant information was not obtained due to presidential power. Recommendations for efficiency and fraud detection in programs and operations are also required. The Inspector General of the Executive Office of the President must submit semiannual reports to the President by April 30 and October 31 each year, including additional information. The President must then transmit the report to specific congressional committees within 30 days, along with any comments deemed necessary. The Inspector General Act of 1978 is amended to make technical and conforming changes, including replacing "subpena" with "subpoena" and reorganizing certain sections. Additionally, an over-classification audit is required by the Inspector General. The Inspector General of the Executive Office of the President, in consultation with the Information Security Oversight Office of the National Archives and Records Administration, will conduct two evaluations to assess classification policies and identify factors contributing to misclassification within the Executive Office of the President. The Inspector General of the Executive Office of the President will conduct two evaluations to assess classification policies and identify factors contributing to misclassification. The evaluations must be completed within one year of each other and will be coordinated with other Inspector Generals and the Information Security Oversight Office to ensure consistency in methodology for cross-agency comparisons. Reports are required as part of the evaluation process. The Inspector General of the Executive Office of the President will submit reports on evaluations of classification policies, including identified factors and recommendations for addressing them. The appropriate entities defined in this subsection include various congressional committees, the President, and the Director of the Information Security Oversight Office.
